tit.cmt: タイトルでは、「ゆだてかぐら」 のみ表記しました。

sen.j: 湯立神楽（ゆだてかぐら/ゆたてかぐら）は日本の伝統的な神楽の形式のひとつ。
sen.e: Yudate-kagura is one of Japanese traditional kagura forms.

sen.j: 釜で湯を煮えたぎらせ、その湯をもちいて神事を執り行い、無病息災や五穀豊穣などを願ったり、その年の吉兆を占う神事の総称である。
sen.e: Yudate-kagura is the general name of religious rites to wish no occurrence of diseases and disasters and rich harvest of five grain crops, etc., and to have the year's fortune told by conducting rites using boiled water which is extremely boiled in a large pot.

sen.j: 同じ湯立神楽でも神社によってかなり違いがあり、玉串に見立てた枝葉を浸して湯を撒くもの（神奈川県藤沢市白旗神社など）や、素手で煮え湯を払うようにして撒くもの（長野県飯田市正八幡神社(遠山郷)など）、全国的にも珍しいご神体を湯につけるもの（香川県丸亀市垂水神社など）などさまざま。
sen.e: The same yudate-kagura even significantly differs by shrine and various forms exist like the ones in which a tree branch compared to tamagushi (a sacred sakaki tree branch) is dipped in hot water and the hot water is splashed (Shirahata-jinja shrine in Fujisawa City in Kanagawa Prefecture, etc.), boiled water is splashed with bear hands as if sweeping (Seihachiman-jinja shrine (Enzankyo) in Iida City in Nagano Prefecture, etc.), the object of worship is dipped in hot water, being rare throughout Japan (Tarumi-jinja shrine in Marugame City in Kagawa Prefecture, etc.), etc.

sen.j: なかには釜湯の中に米やお神酒などを入れるものもある（京都府京都市城南宮など）。
sen.e: Among them, one form also exists in which rice and holy rice wine are put in hot water in a large pot (Jonan-gu shrine in Kyoto City in Kyoto Prefecture).

sen.j: いずれも撒かれた湯（その飛沫）を浴びると無病息災になるとされる。
sen.e: In any of such rites, it is believed that a person who has received the splashed hot water (or its drips) shall suffer no disease and become healthy.
